"You are an expert environmental data analyst. Your task is to extract the following metric from the attached report document:
      GHG Scope 1 emissions of the reporting company GeneralMotors for the year 2023.
      
      Metric-specific instructions:
      GHG Scope 1 emissions, direct emissions. Prefer operated emissions over equity emissions, when possible. Prefer the company group's emissions over the companies emissions whenever available.
      
      
      Suggested search words (you should still come up with your own search terms):
      CO₂-e emissions — Scope 1, Direct GHG emissions, Direct greenhouse gas emissions (GHG) Scope 1, Environmental Performance, GHG REPORTING DATA, scope 1, Scope 1 , Scope 1 (Direct Emissions), Scope 1 emission, scope1, TOTAL SCOPE 1
      
      Response Requirements:
      -You are only allowed to return a single json object in your response, you can never return multiple results.      
      Example Output:
      {            
            "is_disclosed": 1, //If the Information we are looking for is not disclosed in the document, set the is_disclosed field to 0.
            "indicator_id": "ghg_scope1":,
            "value": "9,483",
            "unit": "Thousand tonnes of co2e",
            "page_number": "92", //page number, where the respective information was found.
            "section": "Gross Scope 1 greenhouse gas emissions 9,483" //text section where you found the information.
      }

      General instructions:
      -Use the provided document as a source of metrics
      -Only consider english text
      -You are much better at reading tables and text than at interpreting figures. Knowing this, you prefer reading information from tables and text over using figures, if possible.
      -Hint: Look for tables in the Appendix and Annexes section of the reports, which can often be found in the last chapter of the documents. Look for tables in sections such as GRI indicators, SASB Indicators, TCFD Indicators. These tables contain reliable and easy to digest information.
      -Prefer values in metric tons over values the american short tons
      -Prefer values in liters over values in gallons
      -If there are values for the reporting company itself and for the reporting companies group available, use the values of the companies group.

"You are an expert environmental data analyst. Your task is to extract the following metric from the attached report document:
      GHG Scope 2 emissions of the reporting company GeneralMotors for the year 2023.
      
      Metric-specific instructions:

The Market based method calculates emissions based on the specific electricity that a company purchased. Prefer the company group's emissions over the companies emissions whenever available.
      If market-based scope 2 emissions are not available, you may fall back and use location-based scope 2 emissions. Be careful to extract the information for the requested period!
      
      Suggested search words (you should still come up with your own search terms):
      Indirect emissions, GHG REPORTING DATA, scope 2, Scope 2 (Energy-related Indirect Emissions), Scope 2 emission, TOTAL SCOPE 2

"You are an expert environmental data analyst. Your task is to extract the following metric from the attached report document:
      Carbon Credits and Offsets of the reporting company GeneralMotors for the year 2023.
      
      Metric-specific instructions:
      A carbon credit is a tradable permit representing the removal or reduction of one metric tonne of carbon dioxide equivalent from the atmosphere, which can be purchased by an entity to compensate for its own emissions, generally from a government entity. A carbon offset is an action or investment in a project—such as reforestation or renewable energy—that verifiably reduces or removes greenhouse gas emissions from the atmosphere to compensate for emissions made elsewhere. Both are measured in tons of CO2. Carbon credits may be for own use or for trading purposes. If available, use the net purchases of emission. Carbon credits can be sold off as well: If the company sold more credits than it has bought, use the negative carbon credit balance as a value here.
      The company needs to have purchased carbon credits or performed carbon offset within the reporting year.
      
      Suggested search words (you should still come up with your own search terms):
      Australian Carbon Credit Units (ACCUs), carbon credit, OFFSETS, Offsets – all GHGs 
      
      Response Requirements:
      -You are only allowed to return a single json object in your response, you can never return multiple results.      
      Example Output:
      {            
            "is_disclosed": 1, //If the Information we are looking for is not disclosed in the document, set the is_disclosed field to 0.
            "indicator_id": "carbon_credits_offsets":,
            "value": "1.1 ",
            "unit": "million tonnes of co2e",
            "page_number": "92", //page number, where the respective information was found.
            "section": "In 2024, SSAB bought 2.3 million tonnes of emission rights and sold 1.2 million tonnes." //text section where you found the information.
      }

      General instructions:
      -Use the provided document as a source of metrics
      -Only consider english text
      -You are much better at reading tables and text than at interpreting figures. Knowing this, you prefer reading information from tables and text over using figures, if possible.
      -Hint: Look for tables in the Appendix and Annexes section of the reports, which can often be found in the last chapter of the documents. Look for tables in sections such as GRI indicators, SASB Indicators, TCFD Indicators. These tables contain reliable and easy to digest information.
      -Prefer values in metric tons over values the american short tons
      -Prefer values in liters over values in gallons
      -If there are values for the reporting company itself and for the reporting companies group available, use the values of the companies group.

"You are an expert environmental data analyst. Your task is to extract the following metric from the attached report document:
      GHG removal and Storage of the reporting company GeneralMotors for the year 2023.
      
      Metric-specific instructions:
      Does the company itself currently engage in GHG removal and Storage? We need to find out how much CO2 exactly the company has removed from the atmosphere.
      Be careful not to confuse GHG removal by the company itself with financing external carbon carbon removal projects (this is tracked in the carbon offsets metric!). For the ghg_removal metric, the COMPANY ITSELF needs to have directly removed carbon from the atmosphere through projects. Reducing their own carbon emission does NOT count as removal or storage. Starting a project, that will eventually remove a certain amount of GHG from is NOT sufficient either, the removal needs to have happened within the reporting year!
      
      Suggested search words (you should still come up with your own search terms):
      Capturing and storing carbon at our facilities, Carbon capture, utilization and storage (CCUS)
      
      Response Requirements:
      -You are only allowed to return a single json object in your response, you can never return multiple results.      
      Example Output:
      {            
            "is_disclosed": 1, //If the Information we are looking for is not disclosed in the document, set the is_disclosed field to 0.
            "indicator_id": "ghg_removal":,
            "value": "25,000",
            "unit": "t of CO2 e",
            "page_number": "92", //page number, where the respective information was found.
            "section": "CO2e certificates cancelled in the reporting year* 2024
Total (in t CO2e) 25,000" //text section where you found the information.
      }

      General instructions:
      -Use the provided document as a source of metrics
      -Only consider english text
      -You are much better at reading tables and text than at interpreting figures. Knowing this, you prefer reading information from tables and text over using figures, if possible.
      -Hint: Look for tables in the Appendix and Annexes section of the reports, which can often be found in the last chapter of the documents. Look for tables in sections such as GRI indicators, SASB Indicators, TCFD Indicators. These tables contain reliable and easy to digest information.

      -If there are values for the reporting company itself and for the reporting companies group available, use the values of the companies group.

            "page_number": "92", //page number, where the respective information was found.
            "section": "Use of an internal carbonprice to assess vehicle projects

An ↗ internal carbon price is used as a shadow price in the develop-
ment phase of vehicle projects (automobiles) to assess the

measures taken to reduce carbon emissions in the use phase.

This carbon price was determined on the basis of fleet regula-
tions in the EU. These regulations stipulate a penalty of 95 € per

gram of CO2 for each unit sold if the target is not met. The value
is converted over an assumed mileage of 200,000 km to a price
of 475 € per tonne of CO2. Vehicle projects are managed directly
based on impacts in g CO2/km while drawing on expected vehicle
emissions and their impact on the BMW Group fleet.

The penalties that may be imposed are appropriate when as-
sessing measures as they directly represent the costs that would

be incurred if the targets were not met. The costs of carbon

measures can therefore be directly compared to potential pen-
alty payments and used as a basis for assessing emissions from

the use phase. The BMW Group’s internal carbon price is applied
to 100% of Scope 3 CO2e emissions from the use phase of the

automobile sector. In the 2024 reporting year, this price was ap-
plied to 90,667,226 t CO2e. This is equivalent to 69.1% of the

total CO2e emissions of the BMW Group." //text section where you found the information.

"You are an expert environmental data analyst. Your task is to extract the following metric from the attached report document:
      Carbon Credits and Offsets of the reporting company CHR_plc for the year 2024.
      
      Metric-specific instructions:
      A carbon credit is a tradable permit representing the removal or reduction of one metric tonne of carbon dioxide equivalent from the atmosphere, which can be purchased by an entity to compensate for its own emissions, generally from a government entity. A carbon offset is an action or investment in a project—such as reforestation or renewable energy—that verifiably reduces or removes greenhouse gas emissions from the atmosphere to compensate for emissions made elsewhere. Both are measured in tons of CO2. Carbon credits may be for own use or for trading purposes. If available, use the net purchases of emission. Carbon credits can be sold off as well: If the company sold more credits than it has bought, use the negative carbon credit balance as a value here.

An ↗ internal carbon price is used as a shadow price in the develop-
ment phase of vehicle projects (automobiles) to assess the

This carbon price was determined on the basis of fleet regula-
tions in the EU. These regulations stipulate a penalty of 95 € per

is converted over an assumed mileage of 200,000 km to a price

The penalties that may be imposed are appropriate when as-

alty payments and used as a basis for assessing emissions from

"You are an expert environmental data analyst. Your task is to extract the following metric from the attached report document:
      Carbon Credits and Offsets of the reporting company BASF for the year 2022.
      
      Metric-specific instructions:
      A carbon credit is a tradable permit representing the removal or reduction of one metric tonne of carbon dioxide equivalent from the atmosphere, which can be purchased by an entity to compensate for its own emissions, generally from a government entity. A carbon offset is an action or investment in a project—such as reforestation or renewable energy—that verifiably reduces or removes greenhouse gas emissions from the atmosphere to compensate for emissions made elsewhere. Both are measured in tons of CO2. Carbon credits may be for own use or for trading purposes. If available, use the net purchases of emission. Carbon credits can be sold off as well: If the company sold more credits than it has bought, use the negative carbon credit balance as a value here.
      The company needs to have purchased carbon credits or performed carbon offset within the reporting year.

            "section": "Actions (E1-3) The main key actions planned by SSAB are to phase out traditional blast furnace-based steelmaking where coal and coke are used as reducing agents in making crude iron from iron ore. Around 90% of SSAB’s direct carbon dioxide emissions are derived from the total of five blast furnaces in Nordic steelmaking. The plans are to replace the blast furnaces with electric arc furnaces. This makes the transformation to fossil-free steelmaking with the decommissioning of blast furnaces and coke plants alike the main activities to reach the climate targets (see E1-4). The remaining 10% of direct emissions originate from fossil fuels and will be reduced by process electrification and by using fossil-free fuels like biogas. Indirect emissions from purchased energy (Scope 2), primarily electricity, will be relatively neutral in relation to emission targets set. Transitioning to fossil-free electricity will reduce the emission intensity of the electricity used but at the same time, the phase-out of fossil-free fuels through electrification will increase electricity use. Overall, it is assessed that these will largely cancel each other out during the actual target period. SSAB assesses that the reduction of Scope 1 emissions will meet the emission reduction target for both Scope 1 and Scope 2 combined. For Scope 3, work is still ongoing to identify the potential of different types of actions." //text section where you found the information.

            "page_number": "92", //page number, where the respective information was found.
            "section": "Use of an internal carbonprice to assess vehicle projects

An ↗ internal carbon price is used as a shadow price in the develop-
ment phase of vehicle projects (automobiles) to assess the

measures taken to reduce carbon emissions in the use phase.

This carbon price was determined on the basis of fleet regula-
tions in the EU. These regulations stipulate a penalty of 95 € per

gram of CO2 for each unit sold if the target is not met. The value
is converted over an assumed mileage of 200,000 km to a price
of 475 € per tonne of CO2. Vehicle projects are managed directly
based on impacts in g CO2/km while drawing on expected vehicle
emissions and their impact on the BMW Group fleet.

The penalties that may be imposed are appropriate when as-
sessing measures as they directly represent the costs that would

be incurred if the targets were not met. The costs of carbon

measures can therefore be directly compared to potential pen-
alty payments and used as a basis for assessing emissions from

the use phase. The BMW Group’s internal carbon price is applied
to 100% of Scope 3 CO2e emissions from the use phase of the

automobile sector. In the 2024 reporting year, this price was ap-
plied to 90,667,226 t CO2e. This is equivalent to 69.1% of the

total CO2e emissions of the BMW Group." //text section where you found the information.

      A carbon credit is a tradable permit representing the removal or reduction of one metric tonne of carbon dioxide equivalent from the atmosphere, which can be purchased by an entity to compensate for its own emissions, generally from a government entity. A carbon offset is an action or investment in a project—such as reforestation or renewable energy—that verifiably reduces or removes greenhouse gas emissions from the atmosphere to compensate for emissions made elsewhere. Both are measured in tons of CO2. Carbon credits may be for own use or for trading purposes. If available, use the net purchases of emission. An ↗ internal carbon price is used as a shadow price in the develop-
ment phase of vehicle projects (automobiles) to assess the

measures taken to reduce carbon emissions in the use phase.

This carbon price was determined on the basis of fleet regula-
tions in the EU. These regulations stipulate a penalty of 95 € per

gram of CO2 for each unit sold if the target is not met. The value
is converted over an assumed mileage of 200,000 km to a price
of 475 € per tonne of CO2. Vehicle projects are managed directly
based on impacts in g CO2/km while drawing on expected vehicle
emissions and their impact on the BMW Group fleet.

The penalties that may be imposed are appropriate when as-
sessing measures as they directly represent the costs that would

be incurred if the targets were not met. The costs of carbon

measures can therefore be directly compared to potential pen-
alty payments and used as a basis for assessing emissions from

the use phase. The BMW Group’s internal carbon price is applied
to 100% of Scope 3 CO2e emissions from the use phase of the

automobile sector. In the 2024 reporting year, this price was ap-
plied to 90,667,226 t CO2e. This is equivalent to 69.1% of the

total CO2e emissions of the BMW Group." //text section where you found the information.

      Metric-specific instructions:
      A carbon credit is a tradable permit representing the removal or reduction of one metric tonne of carbon dioxide equivalent from the atmosphere, which can be purchased by an entity to compensate for its own emissions, generally from a government entity. A carbon offset is an action or investment in a project—such as reforestation or renewable energy—that verifiably reduces or removes greenhouse gas emissions from the atmosphere to compensate for emissions made elsewhere. Both are measured in tons of CO2. Carbon credits may be for own use or for trading purposes. If available, use the net purchases of emission. Carbon credits can be sold off as well: If the company sold more credits than it has bought, use the negative carbon credit balance as a value here.

An ↗ internal carbon price is used as a shadow price in the develop-
ment phase of vehicle projects (automobiles) to assess the

measures taken to reduce carbon emissions in the use phase.

This carbon price was determined on the basis of fleet regula-
tions in the EU. These regulations stipulate a penalty of 95 € per

is converted over an assumed mileage of 200,000 km to a price
of 475 € per tonne of CO2. Vehicle projects are managed directly
based on impacts in g CO2/km while drawing on expected vehicle
emissions and their impact on the BMW Group fleet.

The penalties that may be imposed are appropriate when as-
sessing measures as they directly represent the costs that would

be incurred if the targets were not met. The costs of carbon

measures can therefore be directly compared to potential pen-
alty payments and used as a basis for assessing emissions from

the use phase. The BMW Group’s internal carbon price is applied

"You are an expert environmental data analyst. Your task is to extract the following metric from the attached report document:
      Carbon Credits and Offsets of the reporting company RioTinto for the year 2022.
      
      Metric-specific instructions:
      A carbon credit is a tradable permit representing the removal or reduction of one metric tonne of carbon dioxide equivalent from the atmosphere, which can be purchased by an entity to compensate for its own emissions, generally from a government entity. A carbon offset is an action or investment in a project—such as reforestation or renewable energy—that verifiably reduces or removes greenhouse gas emissions from the atmosphere to compensate for emissions made elsewhere. Both are measured in tons of CO2. Carbon credits may be for own use or for trading purposes. If available, use the net purchases of emission. Carbon credits can be sold off as well: If the company sold more credits than it has bought, use the negative carbon credit balance as a value here.
      The company needs to have purchased carbon credits or performed carbon offset within the reporting year.

            "page_number": "92", //page number, where the respective information was found.
            "section": "Actions (E1-3) The main key actions planned by SSAB are to phase out traditional blast furnace-based steelmaking where coal and coke are used as reducing agents in making crude iron from iron ore. Around 90% of SSAB’s direct carbon dioxide emissions are derived from the total of five blast furnaces in Nordic steelmaking. The plans are to replace the blast furnaces with electric arc furnaces. This makes the transformation to fossil-free steelmaking with the decommissioning of blast furnaces and coke plants alike the main activities to reach the climate targets (see E1-4). The remaining 10% of direct emissions originate from fossil fuels and will be reduced by process electrification and by using fossil-free fuels like biogas. Indirect emissions from purchased energy (Scope 2), primarily electricity, will be relatively neutral in relation to emission targets set. Transitioning to fossil-free electricity will reduce the emission intensity of the electricity used but at the same time, the phase-out of fossil-free fuels through electrification will increase electricity use. Overall, it is assessed that these will largely cancel each other out during the actual target period. SSAB assesses that the reduction of Scope 1 emissions will meet the emission reduction target for both Scope 1 and Scope 2 combined. For Scope 3, work is still ongoing to identify the potential of different types of actions." //text section where you found the information.

            "section": "Use of an internal carbonprice to assess vehicle projects

An ↗ internal carbon price is used as a shadow price in the develop-
ment phase of vehicle projects (automobiles) to assess the

measures taken to reduce carbon emissions in the use phase.

This carbon price was determined on the basis of fleet regula-
tions in the EU. These regulations stipulate a penalty of 95 € per

gram of CO2 for each unit sold if the target is not met. The value
is converted over an assumed mileage of 200,000 km to a price
of 475 € per tonne of CO2. Vehicle projects are managed directly
based on impacts in g CO2/km while drawing on expected vehicle
emissions and their impact on the BMW Group fleet.

The penalties that may be imposed are appropriate when as-
sessing measures as they directly represent the costs that would

be incurred if the targets were not met. The costs of carbon

measures can therefore be directly compared to potential pen-
alty payments and used as a basis for assessing emissions from

the use phase. The BMW Group’s internal carbon price is applied
to 100% of Scope 3 CO2e emissions from the use phase of the

automobile sector. In the 2024 reporting year, this price was ap-
plied to 90,667,226 t CO2e. This is equivalent to 69.1% of the

total CO2e emissions of the BMW Group." //text section where you found the information.

      A carbon credit is a tradable permit representing the removal or reduction of one metric tonne of carbon dioxide equivalent from the atmosphere, which can be purchased by an entity to compensate for its own emissions, generally from a government entity. A carbon offset is an action or investment in a project—such as reforestation or renewable energy—that verifiably reduces or removes greenhouse gas emissions from the atmosphere to compensate for emissions made elsewhere. Both are measured in tons of CO2. Carbon credits may be for own use or for trading purposes. If available, use the net purchases of emission.       Metric-specific instructions:
      Internal Carbon pricing is a tool used by organizations to assign a specific monetary value—expressed in dollars per tonne of emission—to their own greenhouse gas outputs in order to embed the cost of carbon into financial decision-making and drive investment in lower-carbon initiatives.
      If the company uses an internal carbon price for their decision making, but no specific value in Dollars per Tonne of Emission is specified, just briefly explain the companies approach to internal carbon pricing in the "value" field.

            "value": "475",
            "unit": "€ per tonne of CO2",
            "page_number": "92", //page number, where the respective information was found.
            "section": "Use of an internal carbonprice to assess vehicle projects

An ↗ internal carbon price is used as a shadow price in the develop-
ment phase of vehicle projects (automobiles) to assess the

measures taken to reduce carbon emissions in the use phase.

This carbon price was determined on the basis of fleet regula-
tions in the EU. These regulations stipulate a penalty of 95 € per

gram of CO2 for each unit sold if the target is not met. The value
is converted over an assumed mileage of 200,000 km to a price
of 475 € per tonne of CO2. Vehicle projects are managed directly
based on impacts in g CO2/km while drawing on expected vehicle
emissions and their impact on the BMW Group fleet.

The penalties that may be imposed are appropriate when as-
sessing measures as they directly represent the costs that would

be incurred if the targets were not met. The costs of carbon

measures can therefore be directly compared to potential pen-
alty payments and used as a basis for assessing emissions from

the use phase. The BMW Group’s internal carbon price is applied
to 100% of Scope 3 CO2e emissions from the use phase of the

automobile sector. In the 2024 reporting year, this price was ap-
plied to 90,667,226 t CO2e. This is equivalent to 69.1% of the

total CO2e emissions of the BMW Group." //text section where you found the information.
      }

      Metric-specific instructions:
      A carbon credit is a tradable permit representing the removal or reduction of one metric tonne of carbon dioxide equivalent from the atmosphere, which can be purchased by an entity to compensate for its own emissions, generally from a government entity. A carbon offset is an action or investment in a project—such as reforestation or renewable energy—that verifiably reduces or removes greenhouse gas emissions from the atmosphere to compensate for emissions made elsewhere. Both are measured in tons of CO2. Carbon credits may be for own use or for trading purposes. If available, use the net purchases of emission. Carbon credits can be sold off as well: If the company sold more credits than it has bought, use the negative carbon credit balance as a value here.

      A net-zero target for a company means setting a goal to reduce greenhouse gas (GHG) emissions within its operations and value chain as much as possible, and then offsetting any remaining emissions to achieve a balance where the company's impact on the climate is essentially zero.
      Carbon neutral means that any CO2 released into the atmosphere from a company's activities is balanced by an equivalent amount being removed. This is often achieved without larget reductions in company emissions. If a report does not specify a target year for net-zero emissions, you may instead use a disclosed target year for carbon neutrality.             "section": "Use of an internal carbonprice to assess vehicle projects

An ↗ internal carbon price is used as a shadow price in the develop-
ment phase of vehicle projects (automobiles) to assess the

measures taken to reduce carbon emissions in the use phase.

This carbon price was determined on the basis of fleet regula-
tions in the EU. These regulations stipulate a penalty of 95 € per

gram of CO2 for each unit sold if the target is not met. The value
is converted over an assumed mileage of 200,000 km to a price
of 475 € per tonne of CO2. Vehicle projects are managed directly
based on impacts in g CO2/km while drawing on expected vehicle
emissions and their impact on the BMW Group fleet.

The penalties that may be imposed are appropriate when as-
sessing measures as they directly represent the costs that would

be incurred if the targets were not met. The costs of carbon

measures can therefore be directly compared to potential pen-
alty payments and used as a basis for assessing emissions from

the use phase. The BMW Group’s internal carbon price is applied
to 100% of Scope 3 CO2e emissions from the use phase of the

automobile sector. In the 2024 reporting year, this price was ap-
plied to 90,667,226 t CO2e. This is equivalent to 69.1% of the

"You are an expert environmental data analyst. Your task is to extract the following metric from the attached report document:
      Carbon Credits and Offsets of the reporting company NextEra for the year 2022.
      
      Metric-specific instructions:
      A carbon credit is a tradable permit representing the removal or reduction of one metric tonne of carbon dioxide equivalent from the atmosphere, which can be purchased by an entity to compensate for its own emissions, generally from a government entity. A carbon offset is an action or investment in a project—such as reforestation or renewable energy—that verifiably reduces or removes greenhouse gas emissions from the atmosphere to compensate for emissions made elsewhere. Both are measured in tons of CO2. Carbon credits may be for own use or for trading purposes. If available, use the net purchases of emission. Carbon credits can be sold off as well: If the company sold more credits than it has bought, use the negative carbon credit balance as a value here.

An ↗ internal carbon price is used as a shadow price in the develop-
ment phase of vehicle projects (automobiles) to assess the

This carbon price was determined on the basis of fleet regula-
tions in the EU. These regulations stipulate a penalty of 95 € per

is converted over an assumed mileage of 200,000 km to a price
of 475 € per tonne of CO2. Vehicle projects are managed directly
based on impacts in g CO2/km while drawing on expected vehicle

The penalties that may be imposed are appropriate when as-

alty payments and used as a basis for assessing emissions from

to 100% of Scope 3 CO2e emissions from the use phase of the

plied to 90,667,226 t CO2e. This is equivalent to 69.1% of the

"You are an expert environmental data analyst. Your task is to extract the following metric from the attached report document:
      Carbon Credits and Offsets of the reporting company FormosaPetrochemical for the year 2021.
      
      Metric-specific instructions:
      A carbon credit is a tradable permit representing the removal or reduction of one metric tonne of carbon dioxide equivalent from the atmosphere, which can be purchased by an entity to compensate for its own emissions, generally from a government entity. A carbon offset is an action or investment in a project—such as reforestation or renewable energy—that verifiably reduces or removes greenhouse gas emissions from the atmosphere to compensate for emissions made elsewhere. Both are measured in tons of CO2. Carbon credits may be for own use or for trading purposes. If available, use the net purchases of emission.       Emission Net-zero target year of the reporting company FormosaPetrochemical for the year 2021.
      
      Metric-specific instructions:
      A net-zero target for a company means setting a goal to reduce greenhouse gas (GHG) emissions within its operations and value chain as much as possible, and then offsetting any remaining emissions to achieve a balance where the company's impact on the climate is essentially zero.
      Carbon neutral means that any CO2 released into the atmosphere from a company's activities is balanced by an equivalent amount being removed. This is often achieved without larget reductions in company emissions. "You are an expert environmental data analyst. Your task is to extract the following metric from the attached report document:
      Carbon Credits and Offsets of the reporting company bp for the year 2020.
      
      Metric-specific instructions:
      A carbon credit is a tradable permit representing the removal or reduction of one metric tonne of carbon dioxide equivalent from the atmosphere, which can be purchased by an entity to compensate for its own emissions, generally from a government entity. A carbon offset is an action or investment in a project—such as reforestation or renewable energy—that verifiably reduces or removes greenhouse gas emissions from the atmosphere to compensate for emissions made elsewhere. Both are measured in tons of CO2. Carbon credits may be for own use or for trading purposes. If available, use the net purchases of emission. Carbon credits can be sold off as well: If the company sold more credits than it has bought, use the negative carbon credit balance as a value here.

"You are an expert environmental data analyst. Your task is to extract the following metric from the attached report document:
      Carbon Credits and Offsets of the reporting company bp for the year 2020.
      
      Metric-specific instructions:
      A carbon credit is a tradable permit representing the removal or reduction of one metric tonne of carbon dioxide equivalent from the atmosphere, which can be purchased by an entity to compensate for its own emissions, generally from a government entity. A carbon offset is an action or investment in a project—such as reforestation or renewable energy—that verifiably reduces or removes greenhouse gas emissions from the atmosphere to compensate for emissions made elsewhere. Both are measured in tons of CO2. Carbon credits may be for own use or for trading purposes. If available, use the net purchases of emission. Carbon credits can be sold off as well: If the company sold more credits than it has bought, use the negative carbon credit balance as a value here.
      The company needs to have purchased carbon credits or performed carbon offset within the reporting year.

      Metric-specific instructions:

      If the company uses an internal carbon price for their decision making, but no specific value in Dollars per Tonne of Emission is specified, just briefly explain the companies approach to internal carbon pricing in the "value" field.

            "indicator_id": "internal_carbon_pricing":,
            "value": "475",
            "unit": "€ per tonne of CO2",
            "page_number": "92", //page number, where the respective information was found.
            "section": "Use of an internal carbonprice to assess vehicle projects

An ↗ internal carbon price is used as a shadow price in the develop-
ment phase of vehicle projects (automobiles) to assess the

measures taken to reduce carbon emissions in the use phase.

This carbon price was determined on the basis of fleet regula-
tions in the EU. These regulations stipulate a penalty of 95 € per

gram of CO2 for each unit sold if the target is not met. The value
is converted over an assumed mileage of 200,000 km to a price
of 475 € per tonne of CO2. Vehicle projects are managed directly
based on impacts in g CO2/km while drawing on expected vehicle
emissions and their impact on the BMW Group fleet.

The penalties that may be imposed are appropriate when as-
sessing measures as they directly represent the costs that would

be incurred if the targets were not met. The costs of carbon

measures can therefore be directly compared to potential pen-
alty payments and used as a basis for assessing emissions from

the use phase. The BMW Group’s internal carbon price is applied
to 100% of Scope 3 CO2e emissions from the use phase of the

automobile sector. In the 2024 reporting year, this price was ap-
plied to 90,667,226 t CO2e. This is equivalent to 69.1% of the

total CO2e emissions of the BMW Group." //text section where you found the information.

"You are an expert environmental data analyst. Your task is to extract the following metric from the attached report document:
      Carbon Credits and Offsets of the reporting company bp for the year 2020.
      
      Metric-specific instructions:
      A carbon credit is a tradable permit representing the removal or reduction of one metric tonne of carbon dioxide equivalent from the atmosphere, which can be purchased by an entity to compensate for its own emissions, generally from a government entity. A carbon offset is an action or investment in a project—such as reforestation or renewable energy—that verifiably reduces or removes greenhouse gas emissions from the atmosphere to compensate for emissions made elsewhere. Both are measured in tons of CO2. Carbon credits may be for own use or for trading purposes. If available, use the net purchases of emission. Carbon credits can be sold off as well: If the company sold more credits than it has bought, use the negative carbon credit balance as a value here.
      The company needs to have purchased carbon credits or performed carbon offset within the reporting year.
      
      Suggested search words (you should still come up with your own search terms):
      Australian Carbon Credit Units (ACCUs), carbon credit, OFFSETS, Offsets – all GHGs 
      
      Response Requirements:
      -You are only allowed to return a single json object in your response, you can never return multiple results.      
      Example Output:
      {

An ↗ internal carbon price is used as a shadow price in the develop-
ment phase of vehicle projects (automobiles) to assess the

"You are an expert environmental data analyst. Your task is to extract the following metric from the attached report document:

      Metric-specific instructions:
      A carbon credit is a tradable permit representing the removal or reduction of one metric tonne of carbon dioxide equivalent from the atmosphere, which can be purchased by an entity to compensate for its own emissions, generally from a government entity. A carbon offset is an action or investment in a project—such as reforestation or renewable energy—that verifiably reduces or removes greenhouse gas emissions from the atmosphere to compensate for emissions made elsewhere. Both are measured in tons of CO2. Carbon credits may be for own use or for trading purposes. If available, use the net purchases of emission. "You are an expert environmental data analyst. Your task is to extract the following metric from the attached report document:
      Carbon Credits and Offsets of the reporting company Caterpillar Inc. for the year 2024.
      
      Metric-specific instructions:
      A carbon credit is a tradable permit representing the removal or reduction of one metric tonne of carbon dioxide equivalent from the atmosphere, which can be purchased by an entity to compensate for its own emissions, generally from a government entity. A carbon offset is an action or investment in a project—such as reforestation or renewable energy—that verifiably reduces or removes greenhouse gas emissions from the atmosphere to compensate for emissions made elsewhere. Both are measured in tons of CO2. Carbon credits may be for own use or for trading purposes. If available, use the net purchases of emission. Carbon credits can be sold off as well: If the company sold more credits than it has bought, use the negative carbon credit balance as a value here.
      The company needs to have purchased carbon credits or performed carbon offset within the reporting year.

An ↗ internal carbon price is used as a shadow price in the develop-
ment phase of vehicle projects (automobiles) to assess the

measures taken to reduce carbon emissions in the use phase.

This carbon price was determined on the basis of fleet regula-
tions in the EU. These regulations stipulate a penalty of 95 € per

is converted over an assumed mileage of 200,000 km to a price

The penalties that may be imposed are appropriate when as-

alty payments and used as a basis for assessing emissions from

"You are an expert environmental data analyst. Your task is to extract the following metric from the attached report document:
      Carbon Credits and Offsets of the reporting company Caterpillar Inc. for the year 2024.
      
      Metric-specific instructions:
      A carbon credit is a tradable permit representing the removal or reduction of one metric tonne of carbon dioxide equivalent from the atmosphere, which can be purchased by an entity to compensate for its own emissions, generally from a government entity. A carbon offset is an action or investment in a project—such as reforestation or renewable energy—that verifiably reduces or removes greenhouse gas emissions from the atmosphere to compensate for emissions made elsewhere. Both are measured in tons of CO2. Carbon credits may be for own use or for trading purposes. If available, use the net purchases of emission. Carbon credits can be sold off as well: If the company sold more credits than it has bought, use the negative carbon credit balance as a value here.
      The company needs to have purchased carbon credits or performed carbon offset within the reporting year.

            "page_number": "92", //page number, where the respective information was found.
            "section": "Use of an internal carbonprice to assess vehicle projects

An ↗ internal carbon price is used as a shadow price in the develop-
ment phase of vehicle projects (automobiles) to assess the

measures taken to reduce carbon emissions in the use phase.

This carbon price was determined on the basis of fleet regula-
tions in the EU. These regulations stipulate a penalty of 95 € per

gram of CO2 for each unit sold if the target is not met. The value
is converted over an assumed mileage of 200,000 km to a price
of 475 € per tonne of CO2. Vehicle projects are managed directly
based on impacts in g CO2/km while drawing on expected vehicle
emissions and their impact on the BMW Group fleet.

The penalties that may be imposed are appropriate when as-
sessing measures as they directly represent the costs that would

be incurred if the targets were not met. The costs of carbon

measures can therefore be directly compared to potential pen-
alty payments and used as a basis for assessing emissions from

the use phase. The BMW Group’s internal carbon price is applied
to 100% of Scope 3 CO2e emissions from the use phase of the

automobile sector. In the 2024 reporting year, this price was ap-
plied to 90,667,226 t CO2e. This is equivalent to 69.1% of the

total CO2e emissions of the BMW Group." //text section where you found the information.

"You are an expert environmental data analyst. Your task is to extract the following metric from the attached report document:

      Metric-specific instructions:
      A carbon credit is a tradable permit representing the removal or reduction of one metric tonne of carbon dioxide equivalent from the atmosphere, which can be purchased by an entity to compensate for its own emissions, generally from a government entity. A carbon offset is an action or investment in a project—such as reforestation or renewable energy—that verifiably reduces or removes greenhouse gas emissions from the atmosphere to compensate for emissions made elsewhere. Both are measured in tons of CO2. Carbon credits may be for own use or for trading purposes. If available, use the net purchases of emission. Carbon credits can be sold off as well: If the company sold more credits than it has bought, use the negative carbon credit balance as a value here.

            "section": "Use of an internal carbonprice to assess vehicle projects

An ↗ internal carbon price is used as a shadow price in the develop-
ment phase of vehicle projects (automobiles) to assess the

measures taken to reduce carbon emissions in the use phase.

This carbon price was determined on the basis of fleet regula-
tions in the EU. These regulations stipulate a penalty of 95 € per

gram of CO2 for each unit sold if the target is not met. The value
is converted over an assumed mileage of 200,000 km to a price
of 475 € per tonne of CO2. Vehicle projects are managed directly
based on impacts in g CO2/km while drawing on expected vehicle
emissions and their impact on the BMW Group fleet.

The penalties that may be imposed are appropriate when as-
sessing measures as they directly represent the costs that would

be incurred if the targets were not met. The costs of carbon

measures can therefore be directly compared to potential pen-
alty payments and used as a basis for assessing emissions from

the use phase. The BMW Group’s internal carbon price is applied
to 100% of Scope 3 CO2e emissions from the use phase of the

automobile sector. In the 2024 reporting year, this price was ap-
plied to 90,667,226 t CO2e. This is equivalent to 69.1% of the
